case_name: Income-tax Officer v. M/s. Bhikaji Dadabhai Co.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that the appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companypetent. Even if the Income-tax Officer companymitted an error

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate authority constituted to hear appeals against specified orders regardless of lower authority's competence; has jurisdiction to review jurisdictional errors of ITO.

holdings.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner had as a court of appeal jurisdiction to determine... even as to his jurisdiction to pass the order appealed from.

anchor.surface_text: in passing the order imposing penalty because the conditions necessary for invoking that jurisdiction were absent, an appeal against his order on the ground that he was not competent to pass the order did lie to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner is under the Act constituted an appellate authority against certain orders of the Income-tax Officer, and exercise of that jurisdiction is not made conditional upon the competence of the Income-tax Officer to pass the orders made appealable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exercise of appellate jurisdiction not conditional on lower tribunal's competence; appellate court determines validity including jurisdiction.

holdings.text: We are, however, unable to agree with the High Court that because of the repeal of the Hyderabad Income-tax Act by the Finance Act, 1950, the power to impose a penalty in respect of the years preceding the date of repeal was lost.

holdings.text: By the Finance Act, 1950, the Hyderabad Income-tax Act was expressly kept alive in respect of periods which include the assessment year in question for purposes of levy, assessment and collection of income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Assessment' in IT Acts means whole procedure for imposing liability including penalty, following Privy Council and this Court precedents; penalty is additional tax.

holdings.text: We are of the view that the High Court erred in holding that the proceedings for imposing the penalty could not be continued after the enactment of s. 13(1) of the Finance Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Messrs. Khemchand Ramdas

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Messrs. Khemchand Ramdas
precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'assessment' in Income-tax Acts has multiple meanings: computation of income, determination of tax payable, or entire procedure for imposing liability
precedents.cited_holding: One of the peculiarities of most Income-tax Acts is that the word assessment is used as meaning sometimes the computation of income, sometimes the determination of the amount of tax payable and sometimes the whole procedure laid down in the Act for imposing liability upon the tax payer.
